document.text: years, delights in telling her i story of the surrender which , took place here April 9, 1865, j just 77 years ago Thursday. Aunt Millie, quaint, timid, and full of interest in her white and negro friends, was active for her age until last spring when she was struck by a bolt of lightning while in bed. She now walks with the aid of a eane, keeps house for her only son. Uncle Bob Craig, who has served as janitor at Appomattox High School for several generations. Aunt Millie was 13 at the time of the surrender and was the nurse maid of Charlie Sackett Peers, six month old son of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Peers. Mr. Peers was at the time clerk of the Court of Appomattox and was living near the scene of the surrender. I was walking de floor, patting my baby to sleep, when those yankee soldiers came bustin in Marse Georges house. document.text: Womans Club Lists Opening Fall Meeting o The first meeting of the Appo mattox Womans Club for the 1955- 1956 season will be held Monday, September 12 at 300 p. m. in the Appomattox High School Cafeteria. Hostesses for the meeting will be Mrs. G. F. Abbitt, Jr., Mrs. H. C. Pulliam, Mrs. J. D. McDeamon and Mrs. H. Y. Spencer. The program for the meeting is designed to acquaint both new mem bers and old with the scope of Womans Club work. The chairmen of the departments will discuss the work of their departments. These include Mrs. F. F. Carr, Chairmen of the American Home Department Mrs. H. A. Gurney, Chairman of Educa tion and International Affairs Mrs. J. R. Lawson, Chairman of Public Affairs and Legislation Mrs. Mil dred Alvis, Chairman of the Welfare Department and Mrs. Roger Nor fleet, Chairman of Fine Arts.  Mrs. Joel W. Flood, Vice-president of the Alice Kyle District of the Vir ginia Federation of Womans Clubs, will discuss the work of Womans Clubs on a district and state level and Mrs. Charles F. P. Crawley will talk about the General Federation of Womans Clubs, which has a total membership of eleven million women. A coffee hour at 300 oclock will precede the business meeting which starts at 330.

document.text: With two straight victories to their credit, the Appomattox high school football boys journey l to morrow to Clarksville to try to make it three in a row. Last Friday, the team played a bang-up game to give the Staunton V. S. D. B . its first defeat in three seasons. The core was 12 to 7. IiLthe quarter, Appo mattox came tu fm behind to mark up the winning tally on a recovered punt fumble, a pass from Tuerman to Cabell and a line buck by Turk man . Tureman turned in a spark ling game in the local backfleld, and the entire Appomattox line played a great game, althought outweighed by Staunton. That Appomattox will have a hard garnT tomorrow is indicated by the fact that Clarksville recently de feated Farmville and lost by only _ one touchdown to Altavista. Several shifts in the line-up may be necessary tomorrow. The mighty atom, Ivanhoe Bryant, is ou. wi n an injured ankle, and R.B. Hudg.ns Jr. and Buck Wallace will fill in  at center for Chuck Lrgon.

document.text: With nearly every eligile voter casting a ballot Tuesday, citizens of the Town of Appomattox named ane automobile dealer, Charles T. Mioses, Jr., as Mayor and another automobile dealer, John S. Ginels as top winner for the six-member Town Council. The Times-Virginian unofficial talley sheet showed Moses ahead, by a dose margin of 220 votes for Mayor to 216 for incumbent Richard D. Robinson. This was the closest race for Mayor here in many years. The ally sheet showed the fol lowing results for Council, with, the top six elected John S. G rin d s ....................... 280 C, Lewis McDeanmon ........... 266 John C, Caldwell . . . . . . . . 261 Grover E. Smith 230 T. Hunter Dickerson . . . . 2215 Clarence C. Poe ................... 269 Mrs. Calvin Roibineon . . . . 206 Ivey Holland ....................... 169 Grover P. Beasley Jr .............. 139 B. H. Guill ........................... 120 J, T. Almond ....................... 11.0 S. J. Evans .......................  . 109 J. T. Irby ................................ 95 The new town officials will take office in September, and serve for a term of two years. The Mayor-elect, Charles Thomas Closes, Jr., is the son of State Sen ator and Mrs. Ohas. T. Moses, of Appomattox. He was born in Appo mattox in August of 1922. He grad uated from Appomattox High School in 1946 and entered Virginia Mili tary Institute in that fall, where he studied until May 1943, when he entered the United States Army as a private. A red letter day in bis life was May 22, 1943, the day on which he received hie War Diploma from Vir ginia Military Institute enlisted .in the U. S. Army and was married to Mies Ruby Martin, the daughter of Mrs. E, B. Martin and the late Mr. Martin, of Oakville. While in the Army, he attained the rank of First Lieutenant in the Combat Engineers. After serving approximately 3 yearn in the mili tary service, inchidingbatii the European and Pacific Theaters, he returned to Appomattox, where he began his business career with the Moses Motor Company, he Chevro let and Oldsmobile Dealership own ed and operated by his father and grandfather, C. T. and T. W. Moses. Charles Thomas and Ruby are the proud parents of three daughters, Joan, Janet and Linda Jo, and an infant son, Charles Thomas, HI, All of the Moses family are mem bers of Memorial Methodist Church, where Charles IteomaD it  member of he Official Board  Charge Lay Leader and a Sunday School teach er. Since his return to Appomattox in 1646, he has been very much in terested -in the .civic affairs of the community. He  helped organize the National Guard Unit at Appomattox and served as its Commanding Of ficer for three years. He has been quite active in the American Le gion, having served aa Commander of the Post 164 for two years, has served as Fourth District Oratorical Chairman for the Legion Depart ment of Virginia, and is a member of the 46  8 Voiture 1133. He is a member and Past Presi dent of the Appomattox Parent- Teacher Association, and is a mem ber of the Appomattox Lions Club. He is a member of the Board of Directors of the Farmers National Bank, and previously served for 3 terms as a member of the Town Council.

The full skirt with in sets of wide lace panels swept into a cathedral train. The fingertip veil of silk illusion was caught to the hair by a band of satin and lace trimmed with sequins and seed pearls. The brides carried a cascade ar rangement of roses and stephanotis centered with a white orchid. Their only ornament was a strand of pearls. Mrs. Shuford selected for her daughters wedding a gown of steel blue, complimented with a white pompom corsage. Mrs. Ferguson wore grey with a white rose pom pom. Mrs. King whs attired in blue and her flowers were white pompoms. The brides parents gave a re ception in the American Legion Hall, which was attractively deco rated with fall flowers. On their return from northern wedding trips, Mr. and Mrs. Fergu son will make their home in Appo mattox and Mr. and Mrs. King will live in Richmond. Both Mrs. Ferguson and Mrs. King are graduates of Madison College. Mr. Ferguson is a gradu ate of Appomattox High School, and is a veteran of World War H. Mr. King is a graduate of Madison College and attended the Univers ity of Virginia. He participated in the Korean War.

Sams father, Howard E. Kerr, was principal of Appomattox High School for a number of years. After graduating from Appo mattox High School, Sam attend ed the University of Richmond where he graduated in 1962 with a BA degree in political science He then attended the T. C. Wil liams school of Law of the Uni versity of Richmond graduating with honors in 1965. While at the University of Richmond he was elected to the ODK N a t i o n a l Leadership Fraternity. While attending law school he was a member of the McNeil Law Soc iety which is an honorary scho lastic fraternity. He was sec retary of the Student Bar As sociation 1963 - 64 and was elected president of the Student Bar Association 1964-65. He passed the Virginia Bar exami nation in 1964 shortly before graduating from law school. While attending the University of Richmond he was a member of the Army ROTC and secured his military training. Upon graduation from law school he entered the Army with the rank of 2nd Lieutenant and was assigned to the Judge Advo cate Generals Corps which is the legal department of the Ar my. document.text: William C. Hubbard, chairman of the Appomattox Civil War Centennial Committee and Mrs. Carrie Gilbert, chairman of the Official Program subcommittee, have made public details of the official program for commemo ration of the 100th anniversary of the Surrender at Appomattox. The afternoons events begin at Appomattox Court House Na tional Historical Park at 140 p.m. with a band concert by the United States Marine Band from Quantico, Virginia. Master of ceremonies for the program to follow at 200 p.m. will be the Honorable John War ren Cooke, chairman, executive committee of the Virginia Civil War Commission. Virginia Military Institute will present colors. An official wel come will be delivered by Gov ernor Albertis S. Harrison, Jr., with the Honorable John War ren Cooke introducing dis tinguished guests. William M. McMillan, Assist ant Postmaster General, will present a Commemorative Stamp Album. Elbert Cox, Regional Direc tor, National Park Service, will introduce Bruce Catton, m a i n speaker for the occasion. A rib bon cutting for the reconstruct ed Court House will follow the 2 p.m. program with Major Gen eral Ulysses S. Grant, HI, and honored guests. Music of Blue and Gray The Appomattox Civic Cho rus is presenting Music of the Blue and Gray on Friday eve ning, April 9, at Appomattox High School. No tickets are be ing sold, but a silver offering will be taken at the door. UDC-American Legion On Saturday, April 10, at 8 p.m. the United Daughters of the Confederacy, American Legion and Legion Auxiliary, will pre sent, a memorial program at the AppqoKUtoElementary School. document.text: Well, I must tell you of the most enjoyable time we students had at Model General Assembly. Our bill, to require all students and faculty members to take a course in civil defense, was passed in the Senate. Because of several other bills con cerning civil defense, ours did not get out. of the House committee. However, a civil defense bill was passed. Edna Gregory, who served as president pro tempore of the Senate, was asked to go to a committee meeting on juvenile delinquency with some state members. Edna was quoted many items from her various comments. We were indeed very proud of her as a representative from our school. As most of us who attended Model Assembly were Sen iors we have a pleasant memory to remind us of our school days. I only hop that through the yeafs the stu dents who go to Model Assembly will gain as much knowledge as we have. The first round of the popularity contest was ended Friday. These five winners will be contestants for Miss Appomattox High School They are  Roberta Harvey, 12th grade Ellen Carter, 11th grade Yvonne Fergu son, 10th grade Clydie Campbell, 9th grade Ida Covington, 8th grade. We have a very fine group of con testants here. Best of luck, girls. The Senior play i9 still progress ing quite well. We are having prac tices every night at the present. Most of us know our parts, thus mak ing it possible to achieve more at practice. The play will be presented April 14th. I do hope that a great many people will he able to attend. document.text: Welcome Home from the Open Road, was the theme of the 5th year Reunion of the 1 46 Gradua ting Class of the Appomattox High School, held on Saturday evening, June 2, in the high school cafeteria A reunion dinner featured the oc casioin. Gypsy music and decorations were carried out for the class theme, The Open Road. The class colors of red and white dominated the room with a background of pines with tent and campfire. Mrs. Mary Spiggre Hudson, vice president of the class, served as toastmistress in the absence of the president, Garland H. Reynolds, who is now serving in the Navy. The toastmistress acknowledged a vacant chair at the head of the table stating, This is in remem brance of our beloved chieftan principal L. Crawley, who has pass ed on higher camping ground. Guests for the evening other than class members included J. A. Burke, superintendent of schools Mrs. J, A. Burke, and Miss Harriett Holley and Mrs. W. M. Morris, class spon sors. Topics of interest to the class members were reviewed as follows Class history, Nellwyn OBrien Class prophecy, Nell Williamson Cabaniss Class mirror, Ann Housman, sec retary of class Last will and testament, Alice Jennings Layne, class treasurer. To the mothers of the tribe the toastmistress presented earrings to bind them and the class closer to gether. The roll was called by the sponsors and each member present answered, giving a brief review if his or her experience on the open road during the past five years. Class members present included

document.text: week H. H. Caldwell, Jr. entered the lists for this office. Commonwealth Attorney It is presumed that the incumbent, G. F. Abbitt, Jr. will file and will be the only candidate. County Treasurer J. Garland Plunkett and Thomas T. Martin ape the announced candidates. David T. Robertson, the incum bent sheriff, was appointed to fill out the term of the late H. W. Mc Kinney, and four years ago won a full term. He was opposed in that election four years ago by Vernell Mitchell. Sheriff Robertson inform ed The Times-Virginian this week that he would be a candidate, and to date no other has announced. The two-way race for Commission er of the Revenue will find H. H. Caldwell, Jr. opposing the veteran incumbent, J. H. OBrien. Mr. Cald- will be making his first bid for public office. He is the son of H. H. Caldwell, of Route 3, Appomattox. He graduated at Appomattox High School in 1943 and entered the Navy as Aviation Cadet August 10 of that year. While in the service he took special courses at the Universities of South Carolina and Georgia. He served on the USS. Bismarck Sea, and was on same when the carrier was sunk by a Jap dive bomber at tack Feb. 23, 1945. He was among the rescued survivors. He entered V. P. I. in the fall of 1945, and re ceived his B. S. degree in 1949. He was president of the civilian student foody his senior year. Since he has been employed with American To bacco Co., Schaffer Pen Co., and since 1954 with Gary Steel Products Corp, Lynchburg, as assistant to the general sales manager..

He graduated from  Appomattox High School hi 1940. At the beginning of World War H, Moon went to   Juliens Creek Ammunition Depot for the Norfolk Navy Yard. In the fitil of 1948 he tfhinteered for service in the U. S. Maritime Service. Following basic training in New York, I went front New York Across country by train to San Francisco and my first voyage out of the country was to New Guinea on a troop ship. I was working in the engine room, commented Moon. Moons travels with the Maritime Service took him to many countries. The war ended in Europe while I was in Russia, said Moon. I came home and Gladys and I were married in 1945. I made one trip, came home and attended Officers School at New London, Connecticut and got my commission. Next I took the Coast Guard examination and attended Diesel School at Sheeps Head Bay. Moon was discharged in August of 1946 and entered VPI to begin his studies in pre-pharmacy. He entered the Medical College School of Pharmacy in 1947 completing his work in 1950. As pharmacist. Moon went to Grays Drug Store in Farmville, then to Rivermont Avenue Phar macy, Patterson Drug Store on Main Street and on Norfolk Avenue

document.text: We extend many thanks to the Appomattox Area 4-Ifers for the work which they put into the Walkathon and also to the many other people assisting with the event. Over 200 young people walked with only fifteen not completing the 10 mile route. A total of over 4,000 was pledged to the people walking. We realize that though the walk is finished some of the most important work - collecting pledges - remains to be done. We urge all of you who walked to collect your pledges and to turn them in as soon as possible. Pledge money may be turned in at the Appomattox County Extension Office, Appomattox Element ary School, Appomattox Ele mentary School, Appomattox Middle School, Pamplin Ele na entary and in the MD box in the office of Appomattox High School. We were happy to have Mr. Norman King, Richmond area Director for the Muscular Dystrophy Association, taking part in the walk. Mr. King completed the entire walk. Once all the pledges have been collected we will announce the winner of the bicycle which will be awarded to the person turning in the most pledge money. Were sorry that we didnt have pictures of the walkathon in progress. Howev er, we did get several right after the walkathon of some of the 200 people that walked. All funds raised in the Walkathon will be given to the Muscular Dystrophy Associa tion to provide for research and service programs provided by the Association. Again, many thanks are extended to the I people walking in the eqent, th o s e a s s is tin g w ith th e Walkathon and those of -you who pledged money to the walkers. We also wish to especially thank the Pepsi Cola Company from Lynchburg, Virginia for providing a concession stand of Pepsis and Dr. Peppers for the walkers at the end of the route. We appreciate their coopera tion and help with this worthy cause. Note also goes to Kings Markets for providing all ice used in providing the refresh ment stands along the route. We hope that we will patronize these sponsors for their help and assistance in this communi ty service project. The following persons walk ed in the 4-H Muscular Dystrophy Walkathon Carroll Almond, Jerome Bell, Percy Bell, Duane Blanks, John Randal Caldwell, Tommy Campbell, E. J. document.text: We are informed that Miss Peggy Henry, of Appomattox High School, lost by a narrow margin yesterday in the Zone finals of the American Legion Oratorical Contest. She had previously won the 4th district contest and was competing with the 1st and 2nd district winners for the right to participate in the State Finals. Peggy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Walter Henry, made an excellent showing in the various contests in which she appeared. The national winner gets a 4,000 college scholar ship. We understand Miss Henry plans to enroll at Vanderbilt University next fall.

document.text: Way land Ferguson repre sented the DECA chapter of Appomattox High School at the 33rd Annual Virginia Distribu tive Education Clubs of America S tate Leadership Conference, The SLC was held at the Hotel Roanoke on March 12-14. While attending the .confer ence Wayland joined approxi mately 600 delegates in electing State Officers and in planning work programs for the coming year for local chapters. Contest finalists from twenty-four Vir ginia DCA districts competed for state awards and the chance to represent Virginia at the National Career Development Conference in Chicago. The conference was high lighted Saturday night starting with a buffet dinner. From 8-10 p.m. an awards ceremony to recognize contest winners was hosted by Kevin Reynolds, who has been the featured Vocalist at the Miss America Pageant. After the ceremony an Awards Ball was given and everyone enjoyed dancing and the music by Reynolds and Co. Mr. Jack Hutcheson, Distri butive Education coordinator at ACHS, accompanied Wayland to Roanoke. Mr. Hutcheson served as a chaperone for the State Leadership Conference. Wayland is a senior at Appom attox County High School and employed by Webbs Tire Company. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. William D. Ferguson, Jr. of Oakville.

Smith was Ever greens first teacher. Evergreens next teacher for the term 1905-06, was Miss Addie Daw son, We have no record or incident of the year she taught. Suffice to say, it was here that Alice Hudson Cheatham Babcock had her start and her intervening fifty years have been spent in a school room. After her graduation from Appomattox High School and Randolph - Macon Womans College in Lynchburg, she took post-graduate work at Colum bia University in New York. She now holds a B. A. and M. A. degree and is assistant principal in one of Columbia, S. C. high schools. At a called meeting of the South- side District School Board held at Appomattox C. H. on August 19 1907, J. C. Jones resigned as clerk and J. R. Hamilton was elected in his place. It is to the late Mr. Hamil ton that we owe our records and most all our information on the early Evergreen school. document.text: WALTER J. PURDY For Lions Anniversary Principal speaker for the Lions Clubs 25th Anniversary dinner here on April 8 at the Appomattox High School cafe teria will be Lion W alter J. Purdy, of Ravenswood, W. Va. Lion Purdy was lected a director of Lions international at the annual convention in Atlantic City June 21. A Lion for more than 33 years, he has served! as club president, deputy district governor, and district governor of W. Va. He is a Master Key member and the recipient of four International Presidents awards. He is owner and manager of the Rural Supply Company of Ravenswood. A member of the Episcopal Church, Lion Purdy is a Mason and a Shriner.

document.text: W. H. Burke, of Roanoke,! spent the week-end here. For Sale or TradeThree fresh cows. Also 2 three-year -old mare colts. L. E. Smith. Miss Mary Phillipson a mem ber of the National Girl Scouts will visit the Appomatox Girl Scouts and have a conference with the leaders Thursday. Dr. J. Franklin Carey, Pre siding Elder of the Lynchburg District, preached at Memorial church here last Sunday. Miss Dorothy Evans, of Rich mond, spent the week-end at the home of C. W. Smith. The Rev. G. D. Coffey is sick. Acid Phosphate Lower 1613.90 ton. H. M. Burge Co., Inc. Appomattox, Va. Dr. George W. Waite, of Richmond, is spending the week in the home of Rev. W. M. Thompson. Miss Virginia Lee Thomp son arrived home yesterday to spend the Easter holidays. Mr. and Mrs. W. S. Green and children, of . Burkeville, Mr. and Mrs W. A, Walton and and son, of Disputanna, will spend Easter in the home of T. A. Walton. Misses Annie Hancoqk, of Crozet and Corinne Hancock, of Franklin, will spend Easter with their parents here, Mr. and Mrs. W. M. Hancock. Walter Scott h a s returned .rom a trip to Norfolk. Edward Scott Cates spent the week-end with his grandpar- nts in Burlington, N. C. The Appomattox chapter U. D. C. meets at the home of Mrs. Lottie Bledsoe Friday at 300 p. m. Mrs. Bledsoe and Mrs. D. N. Twyman will be joint hostesses. Mrs. Betty Stanley has re-, turned from a visit to relatives n Roanoke. J. L. Cates, Jr., who has been sick, is able to be out again. Mrs. Alpha Higginbotham has returned from a trip to Richmond. Mr. and Mrs. A. B. White, of Lynchburg, spent the week-end n the home of L. E- Smith. Miss Margaret Smith will pend Easter holidays here. Mrs. C. A. Carter, of Tower Hill, was In town Saturday Mr. and Mrs. D. E. Walton, of Bent Creek, visited friends here Saturday. The regular weekly meeting of the Womans RecrfTonal Club was held on Monday night at the hall. The Kickers, a division of the club, will en tertain the Pitchers, the other division of the club, at a cover ed dish supper on Thursday. Miss Kate Franklin spent Sunday in Charlottesville. Mr. and Mrs. Norman Cheatham have been sick for he last few days. Miss Frankie McKinney has returned from a visit in Lynch burg R. W. Wilkins attended a Father-Son Benquet, given by he Amherst Chapter of the F. F. A. at Amherst high school on Friday. Misses Ellen Ann and Polly Furbush entertained their club on Friday night. The dedication services of the new Agricultural Building Appomattox high school, will be held on Thursday, March 24, at 7 30. p. m. Walter S. Newman, State Supervisor of Agriculture and F. B. Cale, District Supervisor, will be the principal speakers. Macon Miller, of Lynchburg, will also speak. Over one hundred visi tors are expected. The Appo mattox Chapter of t h e F. F. A will hold a Father and Son Banquet, just before the Dedi cation services of the Agricul tural Building.
